How ju≈øt our War again≈øt you is, and how clearly wee are nece≈øsitated to it, the Parlament hath ≈øufficiently evidenced in their Declaration. And though wee cannot ex≈øpect you ≈øhould acknowledg it (it beeing not u≈øual with you to ≈øpeak truth to your own di≈øadvantage) yet the evidence is ≈øuch as mu≈øt needs convince you, as wee are confident it will ≈øatisfie all others. [2] The in≈øolent and ≈øtrange actings of that prevailing partie of Sectaries in England the≈øe yeers pa≈øt, Warning. in reference to Religion and Government, are ≈øo well known, and have been ≈øo often and fully laid open in the former Warnings, Remon≈øtrances, and Declarations of this Kirk, that wee need not now take up much time in repre≈øenting the ≈øame. as the like hath not been heard of almo≈øt in anie generation: And though Monarchie and the power of Parlaments was the ancient and long continued Government of that Kingdom; yet have tho≈øe men u≈øurped above the Parlament, who≈øe ≈øervants they were; and by open violence driven away manie, and impri≈øoned ≈øom of the Members thereof, and have not onely taken away the Hou≈ø of Lords, and de≈øtroyed the late King, but al≈øo ≈øubverted Monarchie it ≈øelf, and turned the Foundations up≈øide down, and labor to wreath the yoke of their oppre≈øsion upon the necks of our brethren in England, not onely in regard of that which concern's their bodies and e≈øtates, but al≈øo in regard of that which concern's their ≈øouls and con≈øciences, whereof that Ingagement that is now pre≈ø≈øed in England is a pre≈øent and publick te≈øtimonie, being a ≈øore bondage under which manie in that land now groan; who≈øe ca≈øe and ≈øufferings for the work of God, wee de≈øire not onely to remember daily before the Lord in our praiers and ≈øupplications, but in everie thing to regard it as if it were our own: being confident that ≈øuch as love the truth, and cleav to the Covenant in the≈øe Lands, ≈øhall obtein mercie of God to bee faithfull in the mid≈øt of temptations, and that the Lord will not ≈øuffer them to bee tempted above that they are able to bear, but will give unto them the i≈ø≈øue with the temptation.

[2] The wonderful and even miraculous goings forth of the mo≈øt wi≈øe and merciful providence of our good God towards us in England,

work: And though perhaps manie in this age, who≈øe particular concernments have been touched by this ju≈øt hand of God, the flowings of who≈øe gall, by their rebellious ≈øtruglings under their cha≈øtizements, hath di≈øabled their Icterical eyes to ≈øee clearly his hand, may, as you do, bla≈øpheme that Providence, and a≈ø≈øcribe its glorious and harmonious working to the anomalous extravagancies of whom you plea≈ø; yet when the pangs of this birth ≈øhall bee over, and the di≈øtempered humors com again to a ju≈øt ballance, even you, as well as others, ≈øhall ≈øee that it is his doing.
